bibl.title: Letter from Felipe Carbonell Ponce to Philip Showalter Hench, November 22, 1952

div1.p: Carbonell Ponce reassures Hench that the monument will be named the “Monument of Camp Lazear” and that the caseta will remain “Building No. 1.” He has suggested to Nogueira that Hench be acknowledged as the author of the idea of the monument as well as the finder of the caseta.

div1.head: Letter from Felipe Carbonell Ponce to Philip Showalter Hench, November 22, 1952
div1.opener:
Noviembre 22, 1952.
Dr. Philip S. Hench.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester. Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
A few days ago, I spoke to Dr. Nogueira and, after a long con-
versation he made me feel sure that the monument was to be named
“Camp Lazear” and the caseta will keep its name of Building No. 1.
Then after that, I went to see Architect García Meitín, who is an
old school-mate of mine, and he showed me the plan of the monument
where it was wrtten “Monument of Camp Lazear” and he also made me
feel sure that it was going to be that way. Further more, I went
to see Engeneer Dominguez, also an old friend, and he told me the
same thing.

I have been talking to friends of mine that are working at the
Health Department and they all have told me just the same. By
all that I could find out, I feel that it is completly the truth,
that the monument wil be named Camp Lazear and the caseta, Building
No. 1.

I am enclosing a drawing that I made of the plan that García Meitín
showed to me.

When I talked to Dr. Nogueira, I told him that I was sorry to see
that the monument was not to be named “Cuban-American etc... as it
was your original idea, and I also made him know that I believed
that you were the author of the idea and, at the same time, that
you had discovered the caseta, and that you deserved to have a
prominent part in every thing concerning the monument. On account
of what he said, it looks to me, that he is a sincere friend of
yours. Then I suggested to him that something should be done in
the monument to make everybody know the principal part that you
had had in it and I gave him the idea of writing your name in
bronze with a saying that it all was due to your idea and your
finding the caseta and, at the same time, who were you. He answered
that he had in mind something like that and that after a short
time he was going to do it.

As I think that you can be anxious to have news of this question
I am sending you this letter right away, though I promise to write-
giving you more details and being more careful with my english.
I feel afraid that you can not understand some parts of my letter.
My wife joins me in sending our best regards to Mrs. Hench and you
and to the part of your family that we don't know, your children.
